articles.headline: Steep Sell-Off Spreads Fear to Wall Street
articles.snippet: Dizzied by the turmoil, Wall Street experts agreed on one thing: The jarring day showed that fear had finally returned to markets that had become disconcertingly complacent.
articles.abstract: Dizzied by the turmoil, Wall Street experts agreed on one thing: The jarring day showed that fear had finally returned to markets that had become disconcertingly complacent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:10 p.m. | The party is over.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Class-Action Case Accuses G.M. of Neglect Beyond Ignition Switch
articles.snippet: In a strongly worded complaint, the lawyers contend that the “new G.M.” that emerged from bankruptcy in 2009 so valued cost-cutting that it “produced an inordinate number of vehicles with serious safety defects.”
articles.abstract: In a strongly worded complaint, the lawyers contend that the “new G.M.” that emerged from bankruptcy in 2009 so valued cost-cutting that it “produced an inordinate number of vehicles with serious safety defects.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Lawyers in sweeping class-action litigation against General Motors have significantly broadened their case against the embattled automaker, claiming that the company disregarded and concealed safety issues far beyond the defective ignition switch that is now linked to 27 deaths.

articles.headline: Airbnb Listings Mostly Illegal, New York State Contends
articles.snippet: A report by Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, found nearly three-quarters of all Airbnb rentals in New York City were illegal.
articles.abstract: A report by Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, found nearly three-quarters of all Airbnb rentals in New York City were illegal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Airbnb, the pioneering home rental service, presents itself as useful and virtuous, but the reality is far less benign, according to a report that Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, released on Thursday.

articles.headline: In South, Clinton Tries to Pull Democrats Back Into the Fold
articles.snippet: The demand in Kentucky for appearances by Hillary Rodham Clinton underscores the racial and class divisions she would need to bridge if she runs for president again in 2016.
articles.abstract: The demand in Kentucky for appearances by Hillary Rodham Clinton underscores the racial and class divisions she would need to bridge if she runs for president again in 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The last time Hillary Rodham Clinton campaigned in Kentucky, she was delivering her victory speech after defeating Barack Obama in the state’s 2008 Democratic presidential primary on the strength of a huge advantage among white working-class voters.

articles.headline: Downfall for Hospital Where Ebola Spread
articles.snippet: With the announcement that a second nurse in Dallas had been infected, scrutiny of Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital intensified as officials sought to calm workers and patients.
articles.abstract: With the announcement that a second nurse in Dallas had been infected, scrutiny of Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital intensified as officials sought to calm workers and patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Some nurses donned layer after layer of protective garb but unknowingly raised their risk of exposure to the Ebola virus when taking the gear off. Some wore gowns that left their necks uncovered and haphazardly applied surgical tape to the bare spots. And it was two days after the Ebola victim Thomas Eric Duncan was admitted before personnel began wearing biohazard suits.

articles.headline: Cyberattack at JPMorgan Chase Also Hit Website of Bank’s Corporate Race
articles.snippet: Hackers may have infiltrated the JPMorgan Chase Corporate Challenge as a test before the breach of the bank’s internal systems.
articles.abstract: Hackers may have infiltrated the JPMorgan Chase Corporate Challenge as a test before the breach of the bank’s internal systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: The JPMorgan Chase Corporate Challenge, a series of charitable races held each year in big cities across the world, is one of those feel-good events that bring together professionals from scores of big companies.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Nicole Perlroth and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Wall Street Might Know Something the Rest of Us Don’t
articles.snippet: Or, the drop might be simply bringing stock prices more in line with the brutal realities of the economy.
articles.abstract: Or, the drop might be simply bringing stock prices more in line with the brutal realities of the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: By a lot of measures, the United States economy is looking pretty good right now. The unemployment rate has fallen below 6 percent for the first time in half a dozen years, and jobs are being added at the fastest rate since before the Great Recession.

articles.headline: AbbVie Board Recommends Shareholders Reject Shire Acquisition
articles.snippet: AbbVie said its board made the decision after considering the effect of the Treasury Department’s “unilateral changes to the tax rules.”
articles.abstract: AbbVie said its board made the decision after considering the effect of the Treasury Department’s “unilateral changes to the tax rules.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest corporate takeover of the year has essentially been called off.

articles.headline: Life-and-Death Choices in a Himalayan Blizzard
articles.snippet: Scores have been rescued after a blizzard killed at least 27 hikers on one of Nepal’s most popular hiking routes.
articles.abstract: Scores have been rescued after a blizzard killed at least 27 hikers on one of Nepal’s most popular hiking routes.
articles.lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — Freezing, exhausted and blinded by snow, Yakov Megreli, an Israeli medical student, had a few minutes to make a choice.
articles.byline: By Bhadra Sharma, Ellen Barry and Rajneesh Bhandari

articles.headline: Cord-Cutters Rejoice: CBS Joins Web Stream
articles.snippet: The moves by CBS and HBO signal a watershed moment for web-delivered television, where viewers have more options to pay only for the networks or programs they want to watch — and to decide how, when and where to watch them.
articles.abstract: The moves by CBS and HBO signal a watershed moment for web-delivered television, where viewers have more options to pay only for the networks or programs they want to watch — and to decide how, when and where to watch them.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new era of à la carte television arrived in earnest this week — seemingly all at once and more quickly than many industry executives and television fans had expected. And with it, the virtual monopoly that cable, satellite and telecommunications companies have had over TV programming is dissipating.

articles.headline: Obama May Name ‘Czar’ to Oversee Ebola Response
articles.snippet: After learning that a nurse infected in Texas had flown to Ohio, officials in two states closed schools and Americans debated how much they should worry.
articles.abstract: After learning that a nurse infected in Texas had flown to Ohio, officials in two states closed schools and Americans debated how much they should worry.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — President Obama raised the possibility on Thursday that he might appoint an “Ebola czar” to manage the government’s response to the deadly virus as anxiety grew over the air travel of an infected nurse.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Sabrina Tavernise and Abby Goodnough
